t: Job 38
God Speaks Now to Job
Then*p the Lord*s answered Job out of the whirlwind and said,
“Who*pn is this that darkens counsel By*ln words without knowledge?
Now*ln gird up your loins like a man, And*ln I will ask you, and you instruct Me!
Where*ln were you when I laid the foundation of the earth? Tell*ln Me,*i if you have understanding,
Who*ln set its measurements? Since you know. Or*ln who stretched the line on it?
On*ln what were its bases sunk? Or*ln who laid its cornerstone,
When*ln the morning stars sang together And*ln all the sons of God shouted for joy?
“Or*ln who*i enclosed the sea with doors When,*ln bursting forth, it went out from the womb;
When*ln I made a cloud its garment And*ln thick darkness its swaddling band,
And*ln I placed boundaries on it And*ln set a bolt and doors,
And*ln I said, ‘Thus far you shall come, but no farther; And*ln here shall your proud waves stop’?
God’s Mighty Power
“Have*pn you ever in your life commanded the morning, And*iln caused the dawn to know its place,
That*ln it might take hold of the ends of the earth, And*ln the wicked be shaken out of it?
It*ln is changed like clay under*i the seal; And*ln they stand forth like a garment.
From*ln the wicked their light is withheld, And*ln the uplifted arm is broken.
“Have*ln you entered into the springs of the sea Or*ln walked in the recesses of the deep?
Have*ln the gates of death been revealed to you, Or*ln have you seen the gates of deep darkness?
Have*ln you understood the expanse of the earth? Tell*ln Me,*i if you know all this.
“Where*ln is the way to the dwelling of light? And*ln darkness, where is its place,
That*ln you may take it to its territory And*ln that you may discern the paths to its home?
You*ln know, for you were born then, And*ln the number of your days is great!
Have*ln you entered the storehouses of the snow, Or*ln have you seen the storehouses of the hail,
Which*ln I have reserved for the time of distress, For*ln the day of war and battle?
Where*ln is the way that the light is divided, Or*iln the east wind scattered on the earth?
“Who*ln has cleft a channel for the flood, Or*ln a way for the thunderbolt,
To*ln bring rain on a land without people, On*iln a desert without a man in it,
To*ln satisfy the waste and desolate land And*ln to make the seeds of grass to sprout?
Has*ln the rain a father? Or*ln who has begotten the drops of dew?
From*ln whose womb has come the ice? And*ln the frost of heaven, who has given it birth?
Water*ln becomes hard like stone, And*ln the surface of the deep is imprisoned.
“Can*ln you bind the chains of the Pleiades, Or*ln loose the cords of Orion?
Can*ln you lead forth a constellation in its season, And*ln guide the Bear with her satellites?
Do*ln you know the ordinances of the heavens, Or*ln fix their rule over the earth?
“Can*ln you lift up your voice to the clouds, So*ln that an abundance of water will cover you?
Can*ln you send forth lightnings that they may go And*ln say to you, ‘Here we are’?
Who*ln has put wisdom in the innermost being Or*ln given understanding to the mind?
Who*ln can count the clouds by wisdom, Or*ln tip the water jars of the heavens,
When*ln the dust hardens into a mass And*ln the clods stick together?
“Can*ln you hunt the prey for the lion, Or*ln satisfy the appetite of the young lions,
When*ln they crouch in their*i dens And*iln lie in wait in their*i lair?
Who*ln prepares for the raven its nourishment When*ln its young cry to God And*ln wander about without food?
